bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kayâs pêyak nâpêw iskwêwasâkay isiyîhkâsôw ayahciyiniw . Of old a certain Blackfoot was named Skirt.
kitimâkisiw . He was poor.
kîtahtawê mistahi ispatinâhk pa-pimisin . Once upon a time he lay on a hilltop.

kîtahtawê wâpamêw iskwêwah êh-wayawiyit , ê-kî-nipahimiht onâpêmiyiwah , ê-ki-nipahikowit kâhkâkiwacêna . Presently he saw a woman come out of her lodge, a certain woman whose husband had been killed; the Crow Indians had killed him.
êkosi akâwâtêw naha . And so now this man took a fancy to her.
êkosi wâpamêw êh-otinamiyit cîkahikan . He saw her take an axe.
wîwahoyiwa okosisiyiwa . She was carrying her little son.
êkosi sipwêhtêw . So now he went from where he was.
tah oma k-âyât , êkotah ohci pêc-âstamohtêw , wîkihk êh-ohci-sipwêhtêt an îskwêw . Toward the place where he was, the woman came, when she left her tent.
êkosi kâsôhtawêw anah kâ-kitimâkisit ayâhciyiniw . So then the poor Blackfoot hid from her.
êkosi an îskwêw ispatinâhk nanâtawâpiw . Then that woman looked out in every direction from the hilltop.
êkosi êk âwiyah êh-wâpamât , sipwêhtêw êkwah iskwêw ani . Then, when she saw no one, she went away.
- êkosi êh-awasêwêyit , sipwêpahtâw nâpêw anah . As soon as she was round a bend, that man started out on a run.
êkosi êh-wâpamât , kâsôhtawêw . When he got within sight of her, he hid from her.
êkotah nahapiw iskwêw anah . there the woman squatted down.
okosisah ohpimêy êkotah nahayêw , okosisah . She laid her little son down at one side.
êkosi otinam cîkahikan ; êkwah cîkaham asiskiy ; êkwah wâtihkêw . Then she took the axe; she chopped at the ground; she dug a pit.
mâna awa nâpêw piyisk kisiwâk otihtêw awa nâpêw . After a time the man had got quite close to her.
êkwah awah iskwêw pasikôw ; nanâtawâpiw ; êkâ kêkway êh-wâpahtahk , kâwi nahapiw . Then the woman rose to her feet and looked about; when she saw nothing near, she squatted down again.

kwayasitêw , kayâs mahîkhanisisah êh-mônahwât . She went into the pit, digging for old wolflings. LB on {mahîkhanisisah}: The translation given is literal; either the record is wrong, or the word has some derived meaning (name of an edible root?)
otinêw pêyak ; pah-pakamisimêw . She took one up; she flung it on the ground.
êkosi minah kwayasitêw . Then she went into the pit again.
êh-pê-wayawiyit , kawipayihôw , êh-kâsôhtawât . when she came forth again, he threw himself flat on the earth, hiding from her.
mîna kâwi kwayasitêw . Again she entered the pit.
êkosi pasikôw awa nâpêw . At once the man rose to his feet.
wâpamêw , otah iskoh , otêh isi êh-kwayasitêyit , ostikwâniyihk isi . He saw that up to here, up to this point she was in the pit, up to her head.
êkosi êkotah wîwiw ôh iskwêwah . Then he took this woman for his wife.
êkosi aw îskwêw ôtêh , miciminêw ôhi nâpêwa . Thereupon the woman took hold of the man here, like this.
êkosi otinêw okosisah ; wîwahôw okosisah aw îskwêw . she took up her son; the woman carried her son.
êkwah awa nâpêw otinam ocakohpis . The man took his blanket-robe.
êkwah kîwêhtahik . Then she took him home with her.
ê-sâkêwêt , mîkiwâhpihk nakîw awa nâpêw . When he came to the town, the man stopped by a tent.
ohcipitik awa nâpêw . She pulled him on.

âstam ! itêw iskwêw awah ;
âsay kônâpêmimitin . “This way!” that woman said to him; “You are my husband now.”
êkosi sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw . So the man went on.
kîwêhtahik êkwah , pîhtiyisk êh-wîkit aw îskwêw . She took him to her lodge; in the center of the camp dwelt that woman.
êkos îsi pîhtokahik wîkiyihk . So she took him into her tent.
êkosi nahapiwak ôhtapiwinihk awa nâpêw . Then they took their seats on the settee of the man of the house.
miyik . She gave him that privilege.
otinamiyiwa nipiy . She took some water.
kâsîcihcênik ; minah kâsîhkwênik . She washed his hands and face.
êkosi pasikôw aw îskwêw . Then she arose.
êkosi wayawîw ; paspikâpawiw wîkihk . She went out; she stood in the doorway of her tent.
nêkâ ! itwêw iskwêw awa ; “Mother!” she called;

êkosi ,
astêw cî , nêkâ êh-kîsitêk wiyâs ? “Mother, is there any cooked meat?”
pêtâh ! itêw awa iskwêw . “Bring it here!” said the woman.
êkosi pîhtokêw aw îskwêw . Then she came in again.
itohtatâw otânisah wîkiyihk . she went with it over to hed daughter's tent.
otânisah miyêw . she gave it to her daughter.
wâpamêw nâpêwa êh-apiyit ohtapiwiniyihk otânisah . She saw the man sitting on her daughter's settee.
êkosi kîwêw awa nôtokêsiw ; pîhtokêw wîkihk . Thereupon the old woman went back; she went into her lodge.

wîhtamawêw onâpêma :
kitânisinaw êh-wîtapimât nâpêwa . She told her husband of it: “It is that our daughter is sitting by the side of a man.”
awînihih ? itwêw kisêyiniw . “Who is he?” the old man asked her.

êkosi awa nôtokêsiw ,
êyakonih kâ-kitimâkisiyit nâpêwa . Then the old woman, “That poor man.”
êkosi êkwah kisêyiniw awa êh-okimâwit , pêyakoyiwa okosisah ; Now, that old man, who was a chief, had one son;
êkwah ôhi k-ôtinamâsoyit nâpêwa , êyakonih otânisa . and she who had taken that man, she was his daughter.
êkosi nîso pikoh otawâsimisah awa kisêyiniw mînah nôtokêsiw . Only these two children had that old man and old woman.
êkosi nama wîhkâc wayawîw awa kâ-kitimâkisit nâpêw ; And now that poor man never went out of their tent;
nêpêwisiw . he was ashamed.

kîtahtawê ,
âhtokêtân ! itwêwân . Then at one time. “Let us move camp!” said his people.
kinwês êyakoh êh-wîwit . This was when he had been married for quite some time.
êkosi mistahi miyosiw awa nâpêw kâ-wîwit , mâka mistahi êh-kitimâkisit . Now, that man who had married the woman, was very good-looking, only that he was very poor.
êkosi kîksêpâ wayawîw . So now, early one morning, he went out of the tent.
êkosi sipwêhtêw , kont îtê êh-itohtêt , êh-osâm êh-nêpêwisit , mistahi êh-kitimâkisit . He went away, no matter where, for very shame at his great poverty. CHECK: ?? e-osami-nepewisit
êkosi aw ôskinîkiw omisah k-ônâpêmiyit ayâw êh-miywâsiniyikih ayôwinisah ; Now, that young man whose elder sister had taken that man for husband, had some fine clothes;
otêma minah mistahi miyosiyiwa . his horse, too, was very handsome.

êkwah awa nâpêw oskinîkiw otinêw wîstâwa otêmiyiwa ; wiyahpitêw aspapiwin ohci . Then that young man took his brother-in-law's horse and saddled it. LB on {wîstâwa}: I.e., of his sister's first husband.

wîhtamawêw okâwiya :
anihi k-âyât nimis ayôwinisah êkosi ta-pêtâw nimis . He told his mother his plan: “Those garments which my elder sister is keeping, let her bring them here.

seg.gloss: But where has my brother-in-law gone?”

p.seg: aspin ôtê êh-kîh-atimohtêt , itwêw awa oskinîkiskwêw . “He has gone off and away in this direction,” said the young woman.
êkosi nâpêw awa oskinîkiw otinêw misatimwah ; Thereupon the young man took the horse;
ôhi ayôwinisah tahkopitam , êkwah akohp êh-mîkisiwiyik . he tied those garments to the saddle, and a blanket-robe with bead ornaments.
sakâpêkipahêw ôhi kâ-nayahcikêyit , êkwah êh-ntonawât wîstâwah . at a trot he led the horse that was carrying the things, as he looked for his brother-in-law.

aspin wiya êh-wawêyîwiht , ê-wîh-piciwiht , êy-osêhcâyik sâkêwêw êwakô awa oskinîkiw , kâ-ntonawât wîstâwa . Just as his people were making ready to move camp, off went that youth, over the hill, to look for his brother-in-law.
tâpwê miskawêw , itê êh-pmisiniyit . He found him where he lay on the ground.
êkosi êkotah nîhtakosiw . So there he dismounted.

êkosi wîstâwah ,
waniskâh , nîstah ! itêw awa oskinîkiw . Then to his brother-in-law, “Get up, Brother-in-Law!” said that youth.
êkosi êkwah waniskâw awa iskwêwasâkay . So Skirt arose.
êkosi otinamwêw otayôwinisiyiwa ôhi wîstâwa ; Then he took his brother-in-law's garments;
kotakah êh-miywâsiniyikih postayôwinisahêw ôhi wîstâwa . he put other, handsome ones, on his brother-in-law.
êkwah sîkahwêw ôhi mitonih êh-kinwâyikih wêstakayiyiwah . Then he combed him, for very long was his hair.
kâh-kîsi-sîkahwât wîstâwah , êkwah kâsîhkwênêw . When he had combed his brother-in-law's hair, he washed his face for him.
êkwah ê-kîh-kâsîhkwênât , êkwah tômihkwênêw . When he had washed his face, he painted his face for him.

êkosi ,
nîstâh , mistahi kisâkihitn . Then, “Brother-in-Law, I love you very much.

seg.q:
êkâ wiya ê-ntohtawakik oskinîkiwak , mihcêtwâw nntotamâkawin ,
nimis awiya miywêyimâci , t-ônâpêmiw , êh-kîh-itêyihtamân .
seg.gloss: I did not listen when time after time I was besought, for I thought, 'When my sister likes any one, then let her take a husband.'

seg.q: êkosi kit-âyâwat nîstâw otêma , anah kâ-kîh-nipahiht .
seg.gloss: You shall now have the horse of my brother-in-law, the one who was slain.”

p.seg: êkosi pasikôwak . Then they arose.
sipwêhtêwak . They set out.
mistahi miyosiw awa kaskitêwastim kâ-têhtapit awa kâ-kitimâkisit . Very handsome was the black horse which the poor man rode.

tâpwê êh-pimohtêcik awa oskinîkiw ,
tâpwê mistahi miyosiw nîstâw ! itêyihtam awa oskinîkiw . As they went along, “Truly, very handsome is my brother-in-law!” thought that youth.
ôhih mitâsah mistahi mîkisak kikamôwak , êkwah omatôwah mêstakayah mînah . On those leggings were many beads, and these things, scalps, as well.
miskotâkay mistahi mîkisiyiwa ; êwakô kikasâkêw awa kâ-wîwit . The coat was heavily beaded; he wore it, who had married the woman.
êkwah nikikwayân êkotôwahk otastotiniw awa kâ-wîwit . And an otterskin he had as his hat, he who had married the woman.
êkosi êh-otâkosik , ê-sâkêwêcik , âsay kîsi-mânokêwân . Then, in the afternoon, when they came in sight of the place, their people had already pitched camp.
atih-nîhtaciwêwak , êh-ati-nîsicik wîstâwah . They came down the slope, the two brothers-in-law.

êkwah aw îskwêw , êh-pêtisâpamât onâpêma ,
tâpwê miyosiw ninâpêm ! itêyihtam awa iskwêw . Then that woman, when she saw her husband approaching, “Truly, handsome is my husband!” thought that woman.
êkosi takohtêwak wîkiwâhk . So they came to their tent.
êkwah nîhtakosiw . He dismounted.
êkosi aw îskwêw wayawîw . Then the woman came out of the tent.
pîhtokê ! itêw ôhi onâpêma . “Come in!” she said to her husband.
êkosi pîhtokêw awa nâpêw . The man went in.
êkwah aw îskwêw âpahwêw ôhi misatimwa . Then the woman unsaddled the horse.
êkosi sakahpitêw . She tied it up.
êkosi pîhtokêw . Then she came in.
nahapîstawêw onâpêma . She sat down by her husband.
êkosi otinam , êh-asamât , ta-mîcisoyit . She took food and gave him to eat.
êkwah êh-kîsi-mîcisot , êh-tipiskâk , iyikohk wayawîw . When he had eaten, at nightfall, she went out.
wîcêwêw aw îskwêw onâpêma . Her husband went with her.

kîtahtawê pikw îsi mêtawâkâtâw awa oskinîkiw , êh-ohtêyimiht , okimâskwêwa êh-wîwit . Then at one time, in one way or another, people teased that young man, because they were jealous of his having married a chief's daughter.
nanâtohk mâna itâw . They would say this thing and that to him.

seg.q: mihcêtwâw pikw âwiyak nkîh-nôhtê-wîkimik , mâka nama wiya êy-ôhci-nôhtê-onâpêmiyân .
seg.gloss: Many times more than one of them wanted to marry me, and it was only that I did not want to marry them.

seg.q: êkâ wiya wîhkâc nitohtah pikw îsi êh-itikawiyin ; êh-ohtêyimikawiyan , mihcêt nâpêwak êh-kî-nôhtê-wîkimicik .
seg.gloss: Do you never listen when they say foolish things to you, for it is only that you are envied, because many men wanted to marry me.”

p.seg:
kîtahtawê pêhtam ,
ayak pîtos-iyiniwak wâpamâwak . Then at one time he heard, “Some foreign folk have been seen.”

êkosi wîstâwah ,
êkâ wiyah nânitaw t-êtohtêw ; Then his brother-in-law said. “Let him not go, you know where;

seg.gloss: I love my brother-in-law and would keep him.”

p.seg: êkosi tâpwê nama wiya pakitinik wîwa . Accordingly his wife did not let him go from her.

êkosi kotakak êh-kîskotâtocik , ôtah pêmipayitwâwi ,
nam êskwa kikîskotâton . So then, whenever the others went out to the attack, as they went past there, “Not yet have you gone to the attack. CHECK kîskotâto-. HCW: unsure
âsay mihcêt kitôskinîkîmak , itik ôhi kâ-pimipayiyit . Already many of your men have gone,” they who rode past said to him. LB on quote: Apparently I missed the verb.

êkwah ê-sîkawiwiht ,
mahtih nâs nitêm , itêw ôhi wîwah . Then when some of his people had lost their kin, “Suppose you fetch my horse,” he bade his wife.
êkâ wiya ta-sipwêhtêw , kikîh-itik nisîmis , itik wîwa . “'Do not let him depart,' my brother said of you,” his wife replied to him.
kiyâm nâs nitêm , itêw wîwa . “Just you fetch my horse,” he told his wife.
êkosi nâtêw awa iskwêw ôhi kaskitêwastimwa . So then the woman went and got that black horse.
êkosi wiyahpitêyiwa ôhi otêma ; pîhtokêyiwa wîwa . Then she saddled his horse and came into the tent.
nayêstaw kikâsiyânêw awa nâpêw . he kept on only his breech-clout.
osâw-asiskiy misiwê wiyawihk sinikohtitâw , misiwê êy-osâwaskiwastêt êwakô . He rubbed ochre all over his body; he covered himself with yellow clay.
êkosi osikosah pêtohtêyiwa . Then his mother-in-law came hither.

seg.gloss: “Why have you saddled my son-in-law's horse?”

p.seg: wiyahpis , êy-isit awa , itêw okâwiyah awa iskwêw . “Because he bade me saddle it,” the woman answered her mother.
kikîh-kitahamâk kisîmis kitah-sipwêhtêt nnahâhkisîm , itwêw awa nôtokêsiw . “Your brother forbade you to let my son-in-law depart,” said the old woman.
êkosi awa nâpêw wêstakayah tahtinam ; Then the man undid his hair;
ôtah ospiskwanihk asahpitam ; he tied it in a knot at the back.
wîwah nânapâcihik ; tômihkwênik . His wife tended to him; she painted his face.
câpihcicikanis êyak ôtinam . A spear he took.
êkosi astotn , sihkosiwayân-astotn êyakô , êskanak kikamôwak astotinihk . Also a head-dress, a head-dress of weaselskin; horns were fastened on it.
êh-wayawît , ocêmik wîwah . As he left the tent, his wife kissed him.

seg.gloss: “Daughter, do not let my son-in-law throw his life away.

p.seg: mistahi sâkihik wîstâwah mîna osisah , itêw awa nôtokêsiw . His brother-in-law and his father-in-law love him dearly,” said the old woman to her.
êkosi têhcipayihôw otêma . Then he leaped on his horse.
êkosi wâsakâmêw ôma ôtênaw . Then he made the circuit of the town.

seg.gloss: “On this day you shall speak my name.

p.seg:
pimâtisiyânih , ka-nahihonâwâw ,
iskwêwasâkay
t-êtwêyêk , pimâtisiyânih , itwêw . If I live, you will be content to say 'Skirt,' if I live,” he said.
êkosi sipwêpayiw . With that he rode away.
ê-sâkêwêpayit , atimâpamêw ayîsiyiniwah . As he rode over the hill, he saw the men going yon way.

êkosi êtimâci mân êkwah ,
kikîsiskotâtow
itik nâpêwah . And so, as he overtook them, “You are going to the attack, are you?” the men would say to him.
êy-osêhcâk atimâpêmêw , ê-sâkêwêpayiyit wîstâwa êkwah osisa . From a rise in the land he saw his brother-in-law and his father-in-law riding across a ridge.

êh-at-âtimât osisah ,
hâw , nnahâhkisîm , kakwê-pimâtisih ! itik omanâcimâkanah . When he overtook his father-in-law, “Now, my son-in-law, try to preserve your life!” said his tabu-person to him.

êh-atimât wîstâwah ,
âh , nîstah , mistahi kisâkihitn
itik wîstâwah . When he overtook his brother-in-law, “Oh, my brother-in-law, dearly do I love you!” his brother-in-law said to him.

êkosi kitâpamêw :
hâh , nîsta , kisâkihitn nîstah ! itêw wîstâwa . Thereupon he fixed his gaze on him: “Oh, my brother-in-law, I too love you!” he told his brother-in-law.
êkos âti-miyâskawêw wîstâwa . With that he passed his brother-in-law and went on.
pêyak tahkih omisi nâway pâh-pimicipayiwa ; One man always rode about in the rear of the rest;
wâpascimosah têhtapiyiwa . he was mounted on a little white horse.
mayaw êh-atimât , pâskisok . Just as he overtook this man, the latter shot at him.
pêyak êh-atih-nakatimiht nîhciyahkahwêw câpihcicikanis ohci . When one was left behind, he felled him with his spear.
piyisk kêkâ-mitâtaht nipahêw . at last he had killed nine men.
êkoyikohk êkwah tapasiyiwa ôhi wâpascimosah kâ-têhtapiyit . By this time the rider of the small white horse was fleeing.
êkonih nawaswâtêw . He pursued him.
ôtah wanôwâhk kitihkahok . here on his cheek the other grazed him with a shot.
êkos îsi nawatinamwêw têmiyiwa . Then he seized hold of the other's horse.
nîhtakosî ! itêw ôhi pîtos-iyiniwa . “Dismount!” he told the stranger.
êkosi nîhtakosiyiwa . So the other dismounted.
miyin kpâskisikan ! itêw . “Give me your gunl” he said to him.
êkosi miyêw . So he gave it to him.
kimôhkomân miyin ! itêw . “Give me your knife!” he told him.
miyik . The other gave it to him.
êkosi kahkiyaw miyik . So the other gave him everything.
mîna kitastotin ! mîkwana êh-otastotiniyit . “And your head-dress!” - for the other had a headgear of feathers.

êkosi ,
kitêm miyin ! itêw . Then, “Give me your horse!” he told him.
êkosi miyik . So the other gave it to him.
hâw , awa têhtapih , itêw , ôhi kaskitêwastimwah mîskoc êyakonih êh-miyât ; “There, now mount this one,” he told him giving him the black horse in return;

seg.q:
takosiniyani kitaskiwâhk , kitah-âcimowin ; êyak ohci
ptanêh pimâtisit ! k-ôh-itêyimitân .
seg.gloss: When you arrive in your people's country, that you may tell the tale; that is the reason why 'May he live!' is my thought concerning you.”

p.seg: êkosi têhtapiw awa . So he mounted.
êwako awa miyêw otastotin , sihkosiwayân-astotin awa ayahciyiniw , êkwah câpihcicikanis . Then he gave him his head-dress, the headdress of weaselskin, did that Blackfoot, and the spear.
awa kâ-pmâtisit kâhkâkiwacên isiyîhkâsôw . he one whose life was spared was called Crow.
êkosi tapasîw . So then he fled.
êkwah awa ayahciyiniw pêw-otihtik wîstâwah . Then that Blackfoot's brother-in-law came up to him.
mistahi pakwâtamiyiwa ôtah ê-miswâkaniwit ohkwâkanihk . This brother-in-law was very sorry that he had been wounded in the face.
êkosi kîwêwak . So then they went home.

at-ôtinêw kahkiyaw misatimwa awa kisêyiniw , onahâhkisîma tahtoh kâ-pê-nipahâyit , mîna otayôwinisiyiwa , mîna onîmâskwâkaniyiwa . The old man, as he went along, took all the horses of as many as were the men his son-in-law had slain, and their garments, and their weapons.
êkosi êkwah kahkiyaw kîwêwak . So then they all went home.
ê-wîh-takohtêcik , wâhyaw nîkân pimohtêw awa iskwêwasâkay , êwakô , êh-ati-sâkêwêcik . When they had almost arrived, then far ahead went Skirt, as they came into view.
namoya kîh-âkwâskiskawâw , osâm mistah êh-tôtahk ; âsay kaskihisôw êh-okimâwit . No one was permitted to go ahead of him, on account of the great deeds he had done; he had now won the chieftainship.

êkos îsi kahkiyaw ayahciyiniwak mistahi kostik , êh-wâpamiht , mistah êh-pâskisoht , êkosi êkâ êh-pihkwahoht . So then he was greatly respected by all the Blackfoot, when it was seen that he had been much shot at and not seriously wounded.
êh-itêyihtahkik kotakak okimâwak , mistahi kostêwak . When the other chiefs thought of that, they greatly respected him.
nama wîhkâc pêtamâsôw ta-mîcit , pikoh êh-pêtamâht . Never did he need to fetch his food, for always others brought it to him.
êkwah wîstâwah mistahi sâkihik . And his brother-in-law was very fond of him.
êkosi êkwah mistahi okimâwiw . And so he became a great chief.
êkosi êh-nipit , okosisah kîh-okimâwiyiwa , êwakô anah kotak ôhtâwiyah kâ-nipiyit . And then, when he died, his son became chief, the son of the other man who had died.
kaskitêwi-sihkos isiyîhkâsôw . Black-Weasel was his name.
êkosi kahkiyaw . That is all.
